Why I ditched Comodo SSL (and you should, too)

July 1st, 2016

Essentially, at some point a decision was made to anchor trust in an organization like Comodo, and now we‚Äôre locked into trusting them ‚Äî forever.

  • Moxie Marlinspike

The trust we put in Certificate Authorities is highly underestimated in today‚Äôs online world. This is because TLS on the modern web is based on a broken model of trust. There is no trust agility, and this spells doom for everyone. In this article I‚Äôll try to explain how and why.

But why not trust SSL? It says green lock in my browser so it‚Äôs secure, right?

Not really.

Amazon uses it, and so do all the big companies. So it‚Äôs secure.

Still no. Let‚Äôs take Amazon as an example:

  1. You trust Amazon.com with your credit card to buy socks. Because you need socks.
  2. Maybe you did your homework and looked at Amazon.com‚Äôs address bar, which showed a green lock and that looks nice and secure, so ‚ÄúI know I can trust that no man-in-the-middle got my credit card #‚Äù
  3. If you looked a little deeper, you‚Äôd see that Amazon‚Äôs cert is issued by Symantec. They do antivirus software, so that should be fine, right?
  4. Except certs can change at any time. The next day, Amazon starts using one issued by Comodo, because they‚Äôre cheaper. Win for everyone?
  5. You go back to Amazon.com and buy more socks, only this time it‚Äôs a Comodo cert feeding your TLS connection.
  6. You soon get a call from your bank, saying your credit card was cancelled and a new one was issued in the mail. They cited ‚Äúsuspicious activity‚Äù as the cause. What the heck?
  7. Then you read in the news that some hacker issued some rogue certs for Amazon.com. Big deal right?
  8. The hacker set up some DNS spoofing that pointed your Coffee Shop internet connection to 193.293.20.10 (evil server), presenting a ‚Äúvalid‚Äù SSL cert, actually issued by Comodo. Comodo is trusted by browsers, so your browser didn‚Äôt even notice that it‚Äôs talking to evil server and not directly to Amazon.
  9. They proxied your requests to the real Amazon.com, so YOU didn‚Äôt even notice, and for fun they also extracted your CC number, Amazon password, email address, and mail address to their evil server.
  10. SSL didn‚Äôt protect you, it only misled you into (ultimately) trusting a compromised trust chain.

But what if Comodo is now hack-proof and they revoked the bad certs and they‚Äôre fully trustable again?

Sure. But their root CA cert is still trusted by default in major browsers. That means ANY certs they create will be trusted by everyone.

Why is that a problem? I trust Comodo‚Ä¶

What if they wanted to MITM your Amazon.com session for their own purposes? Easy:

  1. Comodo creates their OWN certs for Amazon.com , Comodo owning the private key.
  2. Comodo sets up evil proxies that use that cert and forward to the real Amazon.com
  3. Comodo now owns your ‚Äúencrypted‚Äù SSL traffic to Amazon.com

I don‚Äôt believe Comodo would be that evil.

Well, for a start:

  • They bundled malware into their downloads called PrivDog, claiming to protect users, but actually enabling a MITM attack.
  • They disabled same-origin security in their custom browser, effectively enabling arbitrary MITM attacks.
  • They continued issuing certs used in malware.
  • They declared trademark war on Let‚Äôs Encrypt for ‚Äústealing‚Äù the idea of the ‚Äú90-day free SSL‚Äù.
  • Their CEO is a bit of a douche.

For background, Comodo has a monopoly on SSL certs:

But why would a company with a 40% market share do this?

Comodo sees Lets Encrypt as threat to their monopoly on ‚Äú90-day free SSL‚Äù. Comodo is not free though, it costs roughly $20-90 for a low-level cert. Let‚Äôs Encrypt is free forever.

Why would Lets Encrypt want to offer something for free? I want to pay money in exchange for trust, like I do in other industries.

That‚Äôs where they got you. SSL should be free, because privacy should be a right, and SSL is critical for privacy. Further, introducing a middle-man (Comodo in this case) compromises your privacy, as shown above. Comodo doesn‚Äôt even verify that you own the domain, instead it requires you to respond to an email sent to webmaster@yourdomain.com or similar. It takes roughly 20 mins to set up.

By contrast, Lets Encrypt does real domain validation using a new, open protocol called ACME. Since the whole process can be automated, human intervention (and thus the CA industry) is rendered redundant.

Well, as long as I don‚Äôt buy a Comodo cert I‚Äôm fine, right?

Not exactly. If 40% of the web uses Comodo, that makes 40% of the web compromisable by the same hacker, by hacking a single crypto (root CA) keypair. That is super dangerous for the entire internet. In truth, Comodo has already been hacked, and will probably be hacked again.

OK I give up. I‚Äôll just use CloudFlare to secure and accelerate my site.

CloudFlare specializes in security and performance. Thus, they offer a service that ‚Äúprotects and accelerates‚Äù your website. Oh, and they also register a Comodo cert and use it for your domain:

Wait, doesn‚Äôt that mean they are MITM-ing my site‚Äôs visitors?

Yes! It does. Both CloudFlare (who owns the cert private keys) and Comodo (who can issue any cert) are trusted by all browsers. But why is the trust there? Because of the CA industry, and its influence on browser makers.

I still trust WellsFargo.com to do my online banking, and they use a Symantec cert.

Glad you did your homework, but remember, at any time Wells Fargo could start using a Comodo cert, or even include a single JS file on their site hosted on CloudFlare. If CloudFlare gets compromised (or, inclusively, Comodo), your bank password could be extracted through browser-js injection. Literally any JS file included on any site could exfiltrate passwords or other sensitive data, even if the connection is ‚Äúend-to-end encrypted with TLS perfect forward secrecy‚Äù, as people like to say these days.

Can‚Äôt we remove Comodo from the list of trusted CA‚Äôs?

Maybe, but so many sites were lured into using Comodo because of low prices, that 40% of the web would break if Firefox and Google started blacklisting their certs. And of course, we know that web users hate it when stuff breaks, so web companies (and the web at large) generally won‚Äôt risk breaking changes. That spells doom for the Cryptographic Agility of the web.

Oh great. What now?

  • Use Let‚Äôs Encrypt (or DigiCert, if you have the money). It‚Äôs free and only takes 10 minutes to switch.
  • The catch is that certbot could middle-man your server.
  • We need to make sure Let‚Äôs Encrypt stays open, free, and peer-reviewed. Eventually, perhaps SSL certs will be issued for a small fee by the government(s), for public privacy and security.
  • Then, and only then, can we stop the Comodo monopoly future trust breakdown apocalypse.

Conclusion

As of today, I‚Äôm proud to say I‚Äôm no longer a Comodo customer, and s8f.org now runs on a Let‚Äôs Encrypt cert.
